text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Craburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: THOMAS, MCCRAE

Present Address: 1006, 1st Ave., N.E., MOOSE JAW

Pioneer Address: MOOSE JAW

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1899

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 4 or 5 families

How many of these were bachelor's homes? none in the earliest years

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? only occasionally

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? mostly sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? mostly without invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? afternoon, generally

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? quite often

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) The people visited expected you to stay for a meal; or this was customary

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? coffee, mostly

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? someone left at home, generally

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? The branding, dehorning, or might be a bee

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. once a year or spring & fall no date remembered

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

In later years, when more settlers came in, quite a few house dances were enjoyed in the winter months

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. yes, from 1905 & onward

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? From house to house; but no definite schedule; and weather was an uncertain element every 2 weeks mostly
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting? Each day and fairly 4-3 families.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? None in the earliest years.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Only occasionally.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly weekdays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon, generally.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Quite often.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make polite" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Generally.

6. Did you ever hear when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilting, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling where they were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn every two weeks, once a month, etc.? From house to house; but we didn't schedule it.

were they ever an uncertain element every so weekly mostly
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

No dances were held at school in the first years, but later as homesteaders came in, some social affairs as picnic, Christmas tree & dances were held.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

very little. Church services were held regularly however in later years, this was changed considerably.

9. When was your first community hall built? about 1925

What material was it made of? lumber How large was it? 24 x 36

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community by subscription

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Hamlet

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

The hall was used almost entirely for most social affairs, some schools had the occasional dance.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? quite often

How were babies and small children provided for? The ladies always seemed to manage these things successfully

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? A shed when needed

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Bridge, 5-00 & euchre

Was there card playing for a prize? sometimes

What dances were popular? waltz, fox trot, the French minuet with square dancing predominating

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. no

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

A very odd person were opposed to cards & dancing mostly on religious grounds, very few
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also those on the School Questionnaire.) 

No dances were held at school in the first years, but later on dances came in; some social affairs as family + Christmas, etc., dances were held very little. Church services were held irregularly however in later years, this was changed considerably.

9. When was your first community hall built? about 1925

What material was it made of? Lumber How large was it? 24 x 36

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community by subscription

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Hamlet

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? For example, did you continue to use the school house for all parties, did you continue to use the school house for all parties, did you continue to use the hall in town for other functions, etc., or were you able enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

The hall was used almost entirely for most social affairs, some schools had the occasional dance as affair.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 6, 7, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? quite often

How were babies and small children provided for? The ladies always seemed to manage these things successfully

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? A shed under meadow

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Bridge, 500 & whist

Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes

What dances were popular? waltz, foxtrot, The French minuet

Was there ever any discrimination between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No

Has card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

All very old persons were offered to cards & dancing mostly on religious grounds; very few
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

There didn't seem indulged & do not today in any particular formalities. The calling card would be a joke.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

A few neighbors (generally of the younger type) would congregate & with all the noise making equipment possible would serenade the couple. Quite often a dance would follow.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

In earlier years, a ranch picnic was held, with farmers & families for some distance. The usual games were played & some of the young aspiring brownies, better, would put on a display of wild bronco riding.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The R.M. of Wollboro about 1910

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

The Dept. of Municipal affairs were anxious to have it formed, with a view to more tax revenue, I expect.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

The wheat pool, sometime in the 1920s.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? 75%

How many women belonged? None How often did it meet? Yearly

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

The building of elevators & handling of coal wood

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? There is now

When was it organized? About 1934

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 15 or more

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

They put on some plays, had chicken suppers, dances, card parties, etc.
12. What attitudes at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as yours? How did it manifest itself?

13. Was there a particular favorite place or activity that you enjoyed? Describe what you remember about it.

14. Describe any other details of the event, such as the date, location, etc., that you remember.

15. What was the name of the first organization established in your community? Give the date and reason for its establishment.

16. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? How many women belonged? What were some of the activities carried out by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? How many women belonged? What were some of the activities carried out by this organization?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

In 1932 a branch of the S.G.U was organized; but few farmers joined.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

The usual dances, cards & suppers

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

The community hall at Crestwood

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No. Only political speeches.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

The school pool in later years, would show pictures.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Rarely. Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? The student minister

What were the slides about? Don't remember.

Wild bird life - a talk by Mr. Neil Gilmore, former Game Guardian

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Marbles; but mostly base ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

much the same as boys, mostly ball.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, clubs and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area, (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

Does 1952 a branch of the S.Y.U was organized; but few farmers joined

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

The usual dances, cards & suppers

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

The community hall at Breasted

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands etc.? No

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Yes

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

That were the slides about? Don't remember

Wild third wife - a talk by Mr. Will Gilmore former game gardiner

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Marbles; but mostly base ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Mumble the same as boys, except ball
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? Until lately schools were closed in winter.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? I can't answer these questions.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

Winter time was not a busy time, except the rancher with cattle.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. Jan 1903, in July.

26. Who organized it? Some ranchers.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Everybody.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? The usual picnic events; with bronco riding, as the grand finale.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? The clothes were laid out on the hard prairie. Everyone took his place, wherever convenient.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Tea, coffee, lemonade.

No spread of the present day could outdo the meals of those times; without drinks & ice cream.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? In the early afternoon until nearing sun set.
23. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as Whist, Patience, "Parcheesi," or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

Describe. 

24. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

Describe. 

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

Describe. 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

Describe. 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? 

29. What arrangements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

Describe. 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 

Describe. 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

Describe. 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Describe. 

33. How the early afternoon until evening? 

Describe.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Some young farmers, bought a football & in a short time everybody was chasing this ball. Needless to say many of the old timers were so stiff a sore, that even riding a horse, was extremely painful.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Later years ladies aid or community club had booths, hot dogs sandwiches etc. In later years several schools would hold a sports day & picnic.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

In nearly all cases, several schools held a sports day & picnic. These changes took place about 1934.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

No sports in earliest years. Later foot ball & now baseball. Some older people take part.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Hockey

What year? About 1932 How long did it continue? They still play.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

None before 1914

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). About 1932, hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? None
35. Describe any features of this photo which you remember as outstanding.

36. Describe any different kinds of pictures which you know or in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (baseball, women's basketball, etc.). Tell about any differences in numbers attending, facilities, food and drink, where held, etc.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1941, giving data of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). About 1932, hockey. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? None
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1940
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Replace
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? I don't know
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. None

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
Very few. My wife brought several. Many books were sent us from the east & a growing school began to accumulate books. The authors are many, from Dickens, Dumas, etc.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Not many
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Quite often

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. A few

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?
Ralph W. Conners & others

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Yes
Give details and dates. The county supplied a library at [illegible] about 1920

48. Was there a school library? Later yes When was it begun? X
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Not many

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? I don't think so
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1946

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? No

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? I don't know.

Was there a school library? Later yes

When was it begun? 1920

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Not many

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

very few, my wife bought several, many books were sent us from the east & a growing school book served to accumulate books. The authors are many from Oklahoma, Kansas, etc.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Not many

What kind of books and how many? X

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Quite often

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. A few

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

Ralph borrowed a lot

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Yes

Give details and dates.

The first, supplied a library at

developed about 1920

48. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? I don't think so
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?  
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?  
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

No public library closer than Moose Jaw

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   The Family Herald, The Moose Jaw Times
   + some monthly magazines

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   Discontinued the Family Herald & subscribed for Winnipeg Free Press, Moose Jaw Daily & some farm magazines + Reader's Digest.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Practically all

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   In the long winter evenings, some good books would have been appreciated.
51. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   - When was it started? 
   - Who started it?
   - Is it still in existence?
   - If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

No public library has been known here.

52. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this district?
   - The Family Herald.
   - The Morning Star.
   - The Morning Times.
   - The Evening Star.

Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you subscribed to them, and what others you subscribed to.

Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

53. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

54. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

The long winter evenings, some good books would have been appreciated.
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? A guitar 4 months ago.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   We had a second-hand organ in the earliest years. Later a piano.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   A banjo in 1899 & a piano about 1935.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   A ring song on many occasions.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.
   In later years yes.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Stephen Foster & others.

in the community? The same.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Not popular.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   No.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Entertainment.

56. What musical instruments did you bring next with you? A guitar I would say.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

A buying in 1949 or piano about 1936.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

A very very few musical activities.

In the community (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Stephen Foster.

In the community? The same.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country, you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? When was it started? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Community singing is quite common today, especially at a dance.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I'm not sure when; but my son acquired them somehow also collected stamps.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

My son was quite an authority on birds.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the world?

65. In what way? Give name and date and place of public appearance.

66. In what way? What is the reason for this change?

67. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. In there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?
If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
Oxford.

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.
Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
